'''McBride & the Ride''' is an American [[country music]] band consisting of [[Terry McBride (musician)|Terry McBride]] (lead vocals, bass guitar), [[Ray Herndon]] (background vocals, guitars), and Billy Thomas (background vocals, drums). The group was founded in 1989 through the assistance of record producer [[Tony Brown (record producer)|Tony Brown]]. McBride & the Ride's first three albums — ''[[Burnin' Up the Road]]'', the [[gold album|gold]]-certified ''[[Sacred Ground (McBride & the Ride album)|Sacred Ground]]'', and ''[[Hurry Sundown (McBride & the Ride album)|Hurry Sundown]]'', released in 1991, 1992, and 1993, respectively — were all issued on [[Universal Music Group Nashville|MCA Nashville]]. These albums also produced several hits on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country charts, including the Top 5 hits "[[Sacred Ground (song)|Sacred Ground]]" (their highest-peaking, at No. 2), "[[Going Out of My Mind]]", "[[Just One Night (McBride & the Ride song)|Just One Night]]", and "[[Love on the Loose, Heart on the Run]]".

In 1994, the label removed Herndon and Thomas from the group, which was renamed '''Terry McBride & the Ride'''. McBride remained lead singer, while the other members were replaced with Keith Edwards (drums), Kenny Vaughan (electric guitar), Gary Morse (steel guitar), Jeff Roach (keyboards), and Randy Frazier (bass guitar), formerly of the band [[Palomino Road]]. Roach and Vaughan were respectively replaced by Rick Gerken and Bob Britt shortly before their fourth album (1994's ''[[Terry McBride & the Ride]]''), after which McBride & the Ride disbanded. During the hiatus, MCA issued a compilation called ''Country's Best'', while McBride and Herndon wrote singles for other artists. McBride, Thomas, and Herndon reunited as McBride & the Ride in 2000, releasing ''[[Amarillo Sky (album)|Amarillo Sky]]'' on [[Dualtone Records]] in 2002 before splitting up again. McBride later joined the backing band for the duo [[Brooks & Dunn]] and continued to write singles for other artists, while Herndon self-released a solo album, and Thomas joined [[The Time Jumpers]]. McBride & the Ride re-established a second time in 2021.

==History==
McBride & the Ride was created in 1989 when [[Tony Brown (record producer)|Tony Brown]], then the executive vice president of [[MCA Records]], decided to establish a new country music band in order to compete with [[Alabama (American band)|Alabama]], who he thought was falling out of favor with country radio.<ref name="allmusic"/><ref name="oldies">{{cite web |url=http://www.oldies.com/artist-view/McBride-Ride.html|title=McBride & the Ride Biography |access-date=2007-07-18 |work=Oldies.com}}</ref> At the time, guitarist Ray Herndon (born July 14, 1960) was serving as a backing musician for [[Lyle Lovett]], then a recording artist for MCA. Brown suggested that Herndon join lead vocalist [[Terry McBride (musician)|Terry McBride]] (born September 16, 1958), whom Herndon did not yet know, in the new band that Brown had planned.<ref name="ray">{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1495826/20050112/mcbride_the_ride.jhtml |title=Ray Herndon ready for the spotlight |access-date=2007-07-18 |work=[[Country Music Television|CMT]]}}</ref> McBride, a musician since childhood, had worked as a backing musician for his father, [[Dale McBride]], and later for [[Delbert McClinton]] and [[Rosie Flores]].<ref name="iac">{{cite web |url=http://www.iacmusic.com/artist.aspx?id=26622 |title=McBride & the Ride |access-date=2008-08-02 |work=Independent Artists Company}}</ref> At the Fan Fair (now [[CMA Music Festival]]) in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], Brown introduced McBride and Herndon to drummer Billy Thomas (born October 24, 1953), who had previously played for [[Emmylou Harris]] and [[Mac Davis]], and the band's lineup was in place.<ref name="allmusic">{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p5969|pure_url=yes}} |title=McBride & the Ride Biography |access-date=2007-07-18 |last=Brennan |first=Sandra  |work=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref><ref name="ray"/> Brown had also chosen steel guitarist Steve Fishell to be a fourth member, but Fishell declined and chose to work as a record producer instead. The trio pitched their songs through the assistance of songwriters Bill Carter and Ruth Ellsworth, and four of those demos ended up on the band's first album.<ref>{{cite journal|date=March 1, 1991|title=New artist fact file|journal=Radio & Records|page=47|url=http://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-RandR/1990s/1991/RR-1991-03-01.pdf}}</ref>

==Musical career==
McBride & the Ride performed its first concert in [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]].<ref name="allmusic"/> In 1990, the band released its debut single "Felicia", which peaked at number 74 on the ''[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]'' country charts in Canada in 1990 but did not enter the US country charts. Its followup, "Every Step of the Way", failed to chart in both countries. The band was almost dropped from MCA's roster due to poor chart performance, until the release of "[[Can I Count on You]]", which peaked at number 15 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country charts and was made into a [[music video]].<ref name="allmusic"/> This song's success led to the release of McBride & the Ride's 1991 debut album ''[[Burnin' Up the Road]]'', on which McBride co-wrote all but one of the songs.<ref name="allmusic"/> The last single from this album, "[[Same Old Star]]", peaked at number 28. After the album's release, the band began touring the United States with [[The Judds]] and [[Highway 101]].<ref name="iac"/>

During the band's earliest years, its members were featured prominently on other artists' albums. Thomas also played drums for [[The Remingtons]], a country vocal group featuring former [[Bread (band)|Bread]] member [[Jimmy Griffin]], on its 1991 debut album ''[[Blue Frontier]]'',<ref>{{cite AV media notes |title=Blue Frontier |others=The Remingtons |year=1991 |publisher=[[BNA Records|BNA Entertainment]] |type=CD insert |id=61045}}</ref> while Thomas and Herndon sang [[background vocals]] on then-labelmate [[Marty Stuart]]'s 1991 album ''[[Tempted (Marty Stuart album)|Tempted]]''.<ref>{{cite AV media notes |title=Tempted |others=Marty Stuart |year=1991 |type=CD insert |publisher=MCA Records |id=MCAD-10106}}</ref> Finally, McBride and Thomas sang on the track "How Do I Break It to My Heart" on [[Kenny Rogers]]' 1991 album ''[[Back Home Again (Kenny Rogers album)|Back Home Again]]''.<ref>{{Cite AV media notes |title=Back Home Again |others=Kenny Rogers |year=1991 |type=CD booklet |publisher=Reprise Records |id=26740}}</ref>

''[[Sacred Ground (McBride & the Ride album)|Sacred Ground]]'', the band's second album, came out in 1992. This album was McBride & the Ride's most successful, with all three of its singles reaching Top 5 on the country charts: "[[Sacred Ground (song)|Sacred Ground]]" at number 2, followed by "[[Going Out of My Mind]]" (which McBride co-wrote with [[Kostas (songwriter)|Kostas]]) and "[[Just One Night (McBride & the Ride song)|Just One Night]]," both at number 5.<ref name="allmusic"/> "Sacred Ground" was co-written by [[Kix Brooks]], who had previously released the song in 1989 from his [[Kix Brooks (album)|self-titled]] debut album for [[Capitol Records]] before joining [[Ronnie Dunn]] to form [[Brooks & Dunn]] in 1991.<ref name="oldies"/> In 1992, McBride & the Ride received a Top New Vocal Group or Duo nomination from the [[Academy of Country Music]] and Vocal Group of the Year nomination from the [[Country Music Association]].<ref name="iac"/> More than four years after its release, ''Sacred Ground'' was certified gold by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] for shipping 500,000 copies.<ref name="cmt1"/> Despite these sales, McBride remarked that the band still nearly lost its recording contract, due to other artists on the label selling even more strongly.<ref name="hotels">{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/7702234/terry-mcbride-hotels-highways-new-ep-return|title=Terry McBride to Return with New EP 'Hotels & Highways'|last=Dauphin|first=Chuck|magazine=Billboard|access-date=19 March 2018}}</ref>

McBride & the Ride's third album, ''[[Hurry Sundown (McBride & the Ride album)|Hurry Sundown]]'', was released in 1993. It produced the band's fourth and final Top 5 hit in the number 3 "[[Love on the Loose, Heart on the Run]]" (which Kostas also co-wrote<ref>{{cite AV media notes |title=Hurry Sundown |others=McBride & the Ride |year=1993 |publisher=[[MCA Records]] |type=CD liner notes |id=MCAD-10787}}</ref>), as well as a Top 20 in its [[Hurry Sundown (McBride & the Ride song)|title track]], the only other single release.<ref name="allmusic"/> "Hangin' In and Hangin' On", the [[B-side]] to "Love on the Loose, Heart on the Run",<ref name="whitburn">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc.|year=2008|pages=263|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}}</ref> was later released by [[David Ball (country singer)|David Ball]] as a single from his 1996 album ''[[Starlite Lounge]]''.<ref name="iac"/> In 1994, the band charted its last Top 40 hit, "No More Cryin'", which McBride and [[Josh Leo]] co-wrote for the [[8 Seconds (soundtrack)|soundtrack]] to the film ''[[8 Seconds]]''.<ref name="allmusic"/> The same album featured [[John Anderson (musician)|John Anderson]]'s rendition of the title track to ''Burnin' Up the Road''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/8-seconds-mw0000108154|title=''8 Seconds'' soundtrack|work=Allmusic|access-date=21 March 2013}}</ref> Also that same year, McBride & the Ride recorded a [[cover version]] of [[Southern rock]] band [[Lynyrd Skynyrd]]'s "[[Saturday Night Special (Lynyrd Skynyrd song)|Saturday Night Special]]" on the MCA compilation album ''[[Skynyrd Frynds]]'', which featured country artists' renditions of Lynynrd Skynyrd songs.<ref>{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=r207229|pure_url=yes}} |title=Skynyrd Frynds — Overview |access-date=2008-08-10 |last=Ruhlmann |first=William |work=Allmusic}}</ref>

===Change to Terry McBride & the Ride and first disbanding===
By March 1994, Herndon and Thomas left the group, as the label had decided to shift the band's focus to McBride, and Herndon did not want to be "push[ed] to the background."<ref name="ray"/> According to Herndon, the members "parted as friends."<ref name="iac"/> A new bass guitarist, Randy Frazier, was brought in, also as part of the label's decision to focus more on McBride.<ref name="new"/> Frazier had previously been a member of [[Palomino Road]], which recorded one album for [[Liberty Records]] in 1992.<ref name="new"/> Completing the new lineup were Keith Edwards (drums), Kenny Vaughan (lead guitar), Gary Morse (steel guitar), and Jeff Roach (keyboards), who had previously played in McBride & the Ride's road band.<ref name="oldies"/><ref name="new">{{cite journal |last=Mansfield |first=Brian |authorlink=Brian Mansfield |date=March 1994 |title=McBride & the Ride: Now They Are Six |journal=New Country |volume=1 |issue=1 |pages=11}}</ref> McBride then bought the naming rights to the band and renamed it Terry McBride & the Ride.<ref name="book">{{cite book |title=The Encyclopedia of Country Music |last=Kingsbury |first=Paul |year=2004 |publisher=Sourcebooks, Inc. |location=Nashville, Tennessee |isbn=0-19-517608-1 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=v4GQDYx_RnkC&q=%22mcbride+%26+the+ride&pg=PA333 |page=333}}</ref> One album (also titled ''[[Terry McBride & the Ride]]'') and three singles were released under the new name,<ref name="allmusic"/> with [[Josh Leo]] serving as producer. By the time of the album's release, Rick Gerken had replaced Roach, and Bob Britt had replaced Vaughan. Additionally, only McBride and Morse performed on it, with the rest of the instruments performed by [[session musician]]s and Roach.<ref>{{cite AV media notes |title=Terry McBride & the Ride |others=McBride & the Ride |year=1994 |type=CD booklet |publisher=MCA Records |id=MCAD-11049}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Stambler|first1=Irwin|last2=Laudon|first2=Grelun|title=Country Music: The Encyclopedia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=d18K8QWcEo8C&q=%22mcbride+%26+the+ride%22+%22gerken%22&pg=PA293|date=July 2000|publisher=Macmillan|page=293|isbn=9780312264871}}</ref> The album's singles, "Been There", "High Hopes and Empty Pockets", and "Somebody Will", all failed to reach Top 40, and the band broke up in 1995.<ref name="whitburn"/> [[River Road (band)|River Road]] later released a version of "Somebody Will" from their 1997 self-titled debut album, and [[George Ducas (singer)|George Ducas]] released "[[Teardrops (George Ducas song)|Teardrops]]", a cut from ''Terry McBride & the Ride'', on his 1994 [[George Ducas (album)|self-titled debut album]].

MCA released a compilation package entitled ''Country's Best'' in 1996, which included their first ten singles, from "Felicia" to "No More Cryin'". Herndon and McBride both worked as songwriters during McBride & the Ride's hiatus. Herndon co-wrote [[Kenny Chesney]]'s 1996 single "[[Me and You (Kenny Chesney song)|Me and You]]" with [[Skip Ewing]], while McBride co-wrote several songs for Brooks & Dunn, including the Top Five hits "[[I Am That Man]]", "[[He's Got You]]" and "[[I Can't Get Over You (Brooks & Dunn song)|I Can't Get Over You]]", as well as the Number One "[[If You See Him/If You See Her]]", which featured guest vocals from [[Reba McEntire]].<ref name="cmt1">{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1455371/20020624/mcbride_the_ride.jhtml |title=McBride & the Ride Remount |access-date=2007-07-18 |work=CMT}}</ref> Thomas, meanwhile, worked as a backing musician for [[Vince Gill]],<ref name="cmt1"/> and Vaughan went on to join [[Trent Summar & the New Row Mob]] in 2000.<ref>Whitburn, p. 411</ref>

===Reunion and second disbanding===
In September 2000, Herndon reunited with McBride and Thomas after meeting them at a party at the Handlebar-J Restaurant & Bar in [[Scottsdale, Arizona]], to celebrate the club's 25th anniversary.<ref name="iac"/><ref name="cmt1"/> After they performed "No More Cryin'" there, Herndon suggested that they officially reunite as McBride & the Ride, saying "This thing in my gut was telling me that this was the right time for this."<ref name="iac"/> The trio recorded [[demo (music)|demo]] tapes and began searching for a record deal, signing to the independent [[Dualtone Records]] in 2002.<ref name="cmt1"/> Working with pianist and record producer [[Matt Rollings]], McBride & the Ride recorded its only album for Dualtone, titled ''[[Amarillo Sky (album)|Amarillo Sky]]'', and released it in September of that year.<ref name="allmusic"/> Unlike previous albums, the band wrote most of the songs and played most of the instruments itself because, according to Thomas, "Terry thought this would be even more of a band-like situation if we wrote together more. It would bring us even tighter as a unit."<ref name="iac"/>

Lead-off single "Anything That Touches You" reached number 50 on the country charts in 2002, representing the band's final chart entry. Following it were the non-charting singles "[[Squeeze Box (The Who song)|Squeeze Box]]" (a cover of a song made famous by [[The Who]]) and "[[Amarillo Sky (song)|Amarillo Sky]]." The latter was co-written by [[Big Kenny]] and [[John Rich]] (who would later form the duo [[Big & Rich]]),<ref name="ray"/> and was later recorded by [[Jason Aldean]] on his 2005 [[Jason Aldean (album)|self-titled debut album]]. Aldean's version was released in late 2006 and peaked at number 4 on the country charts in early 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.northplattebulletin.com/index.asp?show=news&action=readStory&storyID=12130&pageID=24 |title=Big & Rich to headline at Comstock |access-date=2008-08-02 |last=Lauby |first=George |date=2007-05-06 |work=North Platte Bulletin |archive-date=2008-10-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081008002951/http://www.northplattebulletin.com/index.asp?show=news&action=readStory&storyID=12130&pageID=24 |url-status=dead }}</ref> Also included on ''Amarillo Sky'' was the track "Hasta Luego", co-written by McBride and previously found on David Ball's 1999 album ''[[Play (David Ball album)|Play]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/play-mw0000244482|title=''Play''|work=Allmusic|access-date=5 August 2014}}</ref>

McBride & the Ride's members disbanded a second time after the release of ''Amarillo Sky''. After this disbanding, McBride became the bass guitarist in Brooks & Dunn's road band. He continued to co-write songs for them, including the Number One hit "[[Play Something Country]]" from 2005,<ref>{{cite journal |last=Horner |first=Marianne |date=2005-10-10 |title=Story Behind the Song: "Play Something Country" |journal=[[Country Weekly]] |volume=12 |issue=21 |pages=70}}</ref> as well as "[[Proud of the House We Built]]", "[[Cowgirls Don't Cry]]", and several album cuts. McBride also co-wrote [[Josh Gracin]]'s 2005 single "[[Stay with Me (Brass Bed)]]" with [[Jedd Hughes]] and [[Brett James]].<ref name="cmt1"/> McBride also produced Hughes's 2004 album ''Transcontinental''.<ref name="hotels"/> Herndon self-released a solo album entitled ''Livin' the Dream'' in late 2005.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rayherndon.net/bio.html |title=Ray Herndon — Livin' the Dream |access-date=2008-07-10 |work=Ray Herndon official website}}</ref> This album included his own rendition of "Me and You" with background vocals from [[Sonya Isaacs]],<ref name="ray"/> and a duet with [[Clint Black]] on "Grain of Salt." McBride has also written for [[Reba McEntire]] and [[Casey James]]. Meanwhile, Thomas toured with the [[Little River Band]], and has joined [[The Time Jumpers]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thetimejumpers.com/members/billy-thomas/|title=Billy Thomas|work=The Time Jumpers|access-date=25 December 2016}}</ref> In late 2017, McBride released an EP titled ''Hotels & Highways''.<ref name="hotels"/>

McBride, Herndon, and Thomas reformed McBride & the Ride a second time in late 2021. In February 2022, the band had their first Nashville concert in 20 years.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-01-27 |title=McBride & The Ride To Play First Nashville Show In 20 Years |url=https://musicrow.com/2022/01/mcbride-the-ride-to-play-first-nashville-show-in-20-years1/ |access-date=2022-06-21 |website=MusicRow.com |language=en-US}}</ref> On November 4, 2022, the band released a new single titled "Marlboros & Avon".<ref>{{cite web | url=https://theboot.com/mcbride-and-the-ride-marlboros-and-avon/ | title=McBride & the Ride Return With New Track 'Marlboros & Avon' | publisher=The Boot | date=November 3, 2022 | accessdate=November 6, 2022 | author=Blake Ellis}}</ref> This was followed in March 2023 by a second single titled "Along Comes a Girl". Both of these songs will be included on an [[extended play]] also titled ''Along Comes a Girl'', slated for release later in the year.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.thecountrynote.com/in-the-news/exclusive-first-listen-mcbride-the-ride-share-sweet-sentiment-with-new-single-along-comes-a-girl/ | title=Exclusive First Listen: McBride & The Ride Share Sweet Sentiment With New Single “Along Comes A Girl” | publisher=The Country Note | date=March 2, 2023 | accessdate=May 20, 2023}}</ref>

==Musical stylings and critical reception==
McBride & the Ride's sound was defined by close, three-part vocal harmonies.<ref name="allmusic"/> Between their vocal styles and the "crisp, gentle rockers"<ref name="ewsacred">{{cite magazine|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,290240,00.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090421155141/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,290240,00.html|url-status=dead|archive-date=April 21, 2009|title=Sacred Ground — Music Review|access-date=2008-11-08|last=Nash|first=Alanna|magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=1992-06-26}}</ref> that the MCA albums contained, McBride & the Ride was compared to other rock-influenced country vocal bands such as Alabama and [[Southern Pacific (band)|Southern Pacific]].<ref name="ewburn">{{cite magazine |url=https://ew.com/article/2001/06/01/burnin-road/ |title=Burning Up the Road — Music Review |access-date=2008-11-08 |last=Nash |first=Alanna |magazine=Entertainment Weekly |date=2001-06-01}}</ref> In his book ''The Encyclopedia of Country Music'', writer Paul Kingsbury describes McBride & the Ride as having "found success with a series of middle-of-the-road singles with tight harmonies."<ref name="book"/>

Ronnie Dunn, with whom McBride collaborated when he wrote songs for Brooks & Dunn, said that he was a fan of the band before McBride joined the duo's road band. In an interview with [[Country Music Television|CMT]], Dunn said, "They're amazingly tight as a group. I first heard them on the radio in the early '90s, shortly after their first single. I liked Terry's singing style. It had a familiar Texas twang."<ref name="cmt1"/> Dunn has also said that he enjoys writing with McBride, because both of them are Texas natives with a similar upbringing and musical influences.<ref name="cmt1"/>

The band's albums have received mixed reception from music critics. ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' reviewer [[Alanna Nash]] criticized the first two albums for lacking strong material outside of "Sacred Ground" (a ballad in which the male narrator tries to convince another man not to commit [[adultery]] on the narrator's wife),<ref name="ewsacred"/><ref name="ewburn"/> but gave ''Hurry Sundown'' a B rating, saying it was "filled with catchy [[hook (music)|hooks]], tight hillbilly harmonies, soulful songs, and[…] a collective personality."<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,307330,00.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090421071351/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,307330,00.html|url-status=dead|archive-date=April 21, 2009|title=Hurry Sundown — Music Review |access-date=2008-12-15 |last=Nash |first=Alanna |magazine=Entertainment Weekly}}</ref> [[Allmusic]] critic Jason Ankeny gave four-and-a-half stars out of five for both the second and third albums, noting of ''Hurry Sundown'' that it "continue[d] to hone the group's close-harmony style."<ref>{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=r169920|pure_url=yes}} |title=''Hurry Sundown'' review |access-date=2008-11-08 |last=Ankeny |first=Jason |work=Allmusic}}</ref> ''Amarillo Sky'' received a three-star review from Allmusic critic Robert L. Doerschuk, who considered it "tight, seamless, [and] a bit impersonal",<ref>{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=r588182|pure_url=yes}} |title=''Amarillo Sky'' review |access-date=2008-11-08 |last=Doerschuk |first=Robert L. |work=Allmusic}}</ref> while [[About.com]] critic Matt Bjorke said it was a "wonderful collection of songs".<ref name="about">{{cite web |url=http://countrymusic.about.com/library/blamarilloskyrev.htm |title=''Amarillo Sky'' - McBride & The Ride |access-date=2008-11-08 |last=Bjorke |first=Matt |work=[[About.com]] |archive-date=2012-03-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120304050406/http://countrymusic.about.com/library/blamarilloskyrev.htm |url-status=dead }}</ref>
